channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Xi Jinping May Delay Picking China’s Next Leader, Stoking Speculation
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China during a ceremony observing Martyrs’ Day, a holiday that memorializes Chinese who died in battle against foreign powers, at Tiananmen Square in Beijing last week.
item.description: The apparent plan by the Chinese president has unsettled the party elite and created uncertainty over whether Mr. Xi will try to stay in power beyond the usual two terms.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China

item.title: Bangladesh Siege Recalled in Militant’s Words, and From Beyond the Grave
item.media:description: A police checkpoint near the site of a bloody siege in Dhaka, Bangladesh, in July.
item.description: An article in an Islamic State publication bears the byline of Tamim Ahmed Chowdhury, a militant who was killed with two associates in a police raid in late August.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and MAHER SATTAR
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Afghanistan and E.U. Strike Deal to Send Asylum Seekers Home
item.media:description: Afghan migrants at a temporary camp on the island of Lesbos in Greece last year. Under a new deal, tens of thousands of migrants, whose asylum applications were rejected in Europe, will be forced to leave.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: The announcement came as the Taliban’s onslaught continued in key areas of Kunduz for a third day, raising questions about urban centers’ security.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Hurricane Matthew Pummels Haiti and Moves Toward U.S.
item.media:description: Streets were flooded in Port-au-Prince after Hurricane Matthew crashed ashore early Tuesday with 145 m.p.h. winds.
item.description: The top United Nations official in Haiti described the storm as “the largest humanitarian event” in the nation of 11 million since a devastating earthquake six years ago.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Winnipeg Journal: A Museum About Rights, and a Legacy of Uncomfortable Canadian Truths
item.media:description: The Canadian Museum for Human Rights in Winnipeg has become a symbol of the contradictions between the nation’s modern multicultural identity and what critics say is an unreconciled legacy of human rights violations against indigenous peoples that continue to this day.
item.media:credit: Aaron Vincent Elkaim for The New York Times
item.description: Backers of the Canadian Museum for Human Rights say it starts important conversations about injustice, but some aboriginal people say it plays down their plight.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: U.S. Election Cycle Offers Kremlin a Window of Opportunity in Syria
item.media:description: The aftermath of Syrian government and Russian airstrikes in a rebel-held neighborhood of Aleppo in July.
item.media:credit: Muhammed Juneyd/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin, analysts say, is advancing goals in the Syrian conflict while President Obama is on the way out and his replacement is undetermined.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Tehran Journal: As Bugs Come for Its Mulberry Trees, a City Wraps Itself in Flypaper
item.media:description: Yellow flytape on park trees in Tehran, Iran. The city is in the midst of fighting a whitefly epidemic that has grown in intensity.
item.media:credit: Newsha Tavakolian for The New York Times
item.description: Solving an infestation of whiteflies in Tehran came down to this: Pray for a long, cold winter to kill their eggs, or cut down all the mulberries. Officials try sticky paper instead.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Theresa May, British Premier, Urges Conservatives to Claim ‘New Center Ground’
item.media:description: Attending the Conservative Party’s conference in Birmingham, England, on Monday.
item.description: Mrs. May, speaking at her party’s convention, sought to court disaffected working-class voters and vowed to rein in abuses by big business.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: A French Underground Railroad, Moving African Migrants
item.media:description: Migrants crossed a road near a Red Cross camp outside Ventimiglia, the last Italian city before the French border. The authorities have put about 800 migrant men in the camp.
item.media:credit: Pierre Terdjman for The New York Times
item.description: Near the border with Italy, a farmer and his network of “citizen smugglers” have helped hundreds cross the border, in a personal response to his nation’s muddled handling of the crisis.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Video May Contradict Ex-ISIS Member’s Claim on Rejecting Violence
item.description: Harry Sarfo, a German jailed in his home country, appears to be shooting toward a man on the ground, although the view is partially blocked.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Sinosphere: Half of Chinese Favorable Toward U.S., but Many See a Threat, Survey Finds
item.media:description: Chinese watching the first United States presidential debate at a cafe in Beijing last week. Half of Chinese surveyed by the Pew Research Center had a favorable view of the United States, up from 44 percent last year.
item.description: Most Chinese want their government to focus on domestic issues rather than helping other nations, the survey also found.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Myanmar Repeals 1950 Law Long Used to Silence Dissidents
item.media:description: President Htin Kyaw of Myanmar and the leader of the National League for Democracy, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, in March. Parliament voted this week to put an end to the Emergency Provisions Act.
item.description: Among other measures, the law had authorized prison terms of up to seven years for reading foreign newspapers or listening to broadcasters like the BBC.
item.dc:creator: WAI MOE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Letter From Europe: ‘Glass Cliff,’ Not Just Ceiling, Often Impedes Women Rising in Politics
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain at the Conservative Party conference in Birmingham, England, on Sunday.
item.description: The theory holds that women are often placed in positions of power when the situation is dire, men are fleeing and the likelihood of success is low.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Sinosphere: As China Strikes Deals, U.S. Considers Expanding Foreign Reviews
item.media:description: Spectators waiting for a film to start at the AMC Loews Kips Bay theater in Manhattan. The Dalian Wanda Group, a Chinese conglomerate, bought AMC Theaters in 2012 for $2.6 billion.
item.description: A government auditing agency will study whether American officials should broaden how they inspect foreign purchases in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Joseph Verner Reed Jr., Protocol Chief Who Presided Over Colorful Gaffe, Dies at 78
item.media:description: Joseph Verner Reed Jr., right, with President George Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev in 1990.
item.media:credit: Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times
item.description: While under President George Bush, Mr. Reed was part of ‘the talking hat’ affair, a slip-up that entered the annals of diplomatic history.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM GRIMES

item.title: Joshua Wong, Hong Kong Democracy Leader, Is Detained at Bangkok Airport
item.media:description: The democracy campaigner Joshua Wong at the Hong Kong airport on Wednesday, after being sent back from Thailand, where he had been scheduled to speak.
item.description: Mr. Wong, 19, said after returning to Hong Kong that he had been held with little explanation from Thai officials, who he said had “mentioned a blacklist.”
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG and EDWARD WONG

item.title: Colombia and Rebels Want Peace, but How Has Never Been Less Clear.
item.media:description: Homes destroyed by bombs in Toribío, a town in western Colombia. The country’s 52-year war was supposed to be over by now.
item.description: After the defeat of a peace deal, the range of possibilities is dizzying, from quick talks to produce an amended agreement to an effort to rewrite the Constitution.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE and NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Trinh Thi Ngo, Broadcaster Called ‘Hanoi Hannah’ in Vietnam War, Dies
item.media:description: Trinh Thi Ngo, better known as “Hanoi Hannah,” in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, last year.
item.description: The soft-spoken radio announcer both entertained and reproached American forces.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: German Prosecutors Side With Satire, Not Turkish President
item.media:description: Jan Böhmermann
item.description: Prosecutors saw no crime in a satirical poem about Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the Turkish president, and dropped charges against a German comedian.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Improvised Bomb Kills U.S. Service Member in Afghanistan
item.description: The service member, the third American killed in hostilities in Afghanistan this year, was on a mission against Islamic State fighters in Nangarhar Province.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Iran, Which Executed Nearly 1,000 Last Year, Considers Cutting Back
item.description: A new bill would end capital punishment for drug smugglers, who accounted for most of the country’s hundreds of executions last year, but hard-liners oppose it.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: A List of Previous Disasters in Haiti, a Land All Too Familiar With Hardship
item.media:description: A girl watching as the authorities evacuated her home in Tabarre, Haiti, on Monday before a dangerous storm.
item.description: The country’s location in the Caribbean and on the Gonâve microplate makes it highly vulnerable to tropical storms and earthquakes.
item.dc:creator: INYOUNG KANG

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte, Philippines’ Leader, Says Obama ‘Can Go to Hell’
item.description: Mr. Duterte, whose government is carrying out a deadly war on drugs, was angered by what he said was the United States’ refusal to sell weapons to the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Pope Francis Makes Surprise Visit to Earthquake-Hit Towns in Italy
item.media:description: Pope Francis praying during a visit to San Pellegrino di Norcia, Italy, on Tuesday.
item.description: Francis vowed after the deadly tremor that he would travel to the region and pray with residents, but he had delayed the trip to avoid hindering rebuilding efforts.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: John Kerry Criticizes Russia, Saying It ‘Turned a Blind Eye’ on Syria
item.description: The secretary of state said Moscow ignored President Bashar al-Assad’s use of chlorine gas and barrel bombs against his own people.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese Tourists Take to the Road in Record Numbers for Golden Week
item.media:description: A record number of Chinese have hit the road this week for the National Day holiday, including these tourists crossing a bridge at West Lake in Hangzhou, Zhejiang Province.
item.description: People’s Daily, the Communist Party newspaper, said 589 million people were expected to travel this week — almost twice the population of the United States.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Julian Assange, WikiLeaks Founder, Promises Raft of Revelations
item.description: On his organization’s 10th anniversary, he vowed to release “significant material” about a range of issues, including the U.S. election.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Australians Arrested in Malaysia After Stripping to Briefs at Grand Prix
item.media:description: Spectators with swimwear bearing a Malaysian flag at the Malaysian Grand Prix in Sepang on Sunday.
item.description: Nine men, including one said to be an aide to a cabinet minister, shed their clothes to reveal briefs that featured Malaysia’s flag.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES and MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: 3 Who Studied Unusual States of Matter Win Nobel Prize in Physics
item.media:description: F. Duncan M. Haldane, a British scientist at Princeton University, at his home in New Jersey.
item.description: David J. Thouless, F. Duncan M. Haldane and J. Michael Kosterlitz were recognized for transforming the understanding of matter that assumes strange shapes.
item.dc:creator: DENNIS OVERBYE and SEWELL CHAN

item.title: The Interpreter: Why Referendums Aren’t as Democratic as They Seem
item.media:description: Opponents of the Colombian peace agreement celebrating on Sunday in Bogotá, the capital, after the results of a national referendum were announced.
item.description: Though such votes are portrayed as popular governance in its purest form, studies have found that they often subvert democracy rather than serve it.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB and MAX FISHER

item.title: Afghan Forces Push Taliban Out of Kunduz Center, Officials Say
item.media:description: Security forces in Kunduz, Afghanistan, on Tuesday. Afghan officials said that their commando forces had reclaimed the main city square from the Taliban.
item.description: After Afghan commandos arrived to battle an insurgent assault on the critical city, residents said that heavy fighting was spreading to other areas.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and NAJIM RAHIM

item.title: What in the World: In Senegal, Absolution Comes With a Wing and a Prayer
item.description: In Dakar and other cities, men stand on street corners with cages of red-billed firefinches, which people buy and release to get rid of sins and anxiety.
item.dc:creator: JAIME YAYA BARRY

item.title: What in the World: Need to Land a Plane? In Australia, They Break Out the Toilet Paper
item.description: For the Royal Flying Doctor Service to arrive and land on a remote runway at night, about 30 cans with flaming rolls sometimes have to be lined up.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: Royal Flying Doctor Service of Australia

item.title: Editorial: President Duterte, the Wild Card in U.S.-Filipino Relations
item.media:description: Police block protesters trying to get near the U.S. embassy in Manila during a rally against the Enhanced Defense Cooperation Agreement on Tuesday.
item.description: In his three months in office, President Rodrigo Duterte has found many ways to damage his country’s ties to America.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Sociology, According to Putin
item.media:description: Lev D. Gudkov, director of the Levada Center, Russia’s only reputable independent polling organization, in 2013.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: The Kremlin fears sociologists even more than it needs them.
item.dc:creator: MASHA GESSEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Can Colombia Overcome Fear to Achieve Peace?
item.description: If the opponents of peace refuse to compromise, the country will stagnate as a society, as an economy, and as a democracy.
item.dc:creator: JAIME ABELLO BANFI

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
